text: [Music]
hello this is chef john from
foodwishes.com
with
sloppy toms and what's a sloppy tom it's
a sloppy joe made with turkey and what's
a sloppy joe well it's a variation on
something called a loose meat sandwich
and what's a loose meat sandwich uh you
don't want to know but anyway this is
very delicious easy to make and here is
how you do it all right in a heavy
skillet i'm going to melt some butter
over medium heat i'm going to toss in a
diced onion and a big pinch of salt and
i sauteed that onion until just
translucent which in hindsight i should
have gone a little further but i think
the color of this could have been a
little deeper and i think right here
going past translucent to more of a
golden brown to even a light brown i
think would have been a good idea all
right to our sauteed onions i'm gonna
add turkey ground turkey meat very lean
potentially very dry and chalky and for
that reason i'm not gonna actually brown
the turkey i'm going to mix it into the
onions with a little bit of water and
turn it into more of a paste so i can
kind of cook that down and get that
desired texture that i'm looking for
something very soft and succulent and
not dry and chalky so basically just
keep it over medium heat take your
spatula or your wooden spoon or whatever
you're using and just keep crushing it
and mixing it and smashing it down into
as small a pieces as possible okay and
that's just going to take a couple
minutes and when it looks something like
that we're gonna go ahead and add in a
little bit of brown sugar
and ketchup so your basic sloppy joe
flavor profile is ground meat slightly
sweet slightly spicy
balanced by that tomatoey tartness from
the ketchup okay so very important don't
be using fresh tomatoes in this don't be
getting all gourmet you want to stick
with the ketchup here so once that's all
stirred in we're going to season it up a
little bit with some freshly ground
black pepper definitely some cayenne and
a good amount of it season to taste with
salt of course you knew that was coming
so i stirred in the seasonings and i let
this cook for about five minutes while i
pondered what else should i put in here
so many potential secret ingredients and
so little time but anyway five minutes
later i decided to finish this off with
a little worshier sauce and i hope
you're sitting down a little pinch of
unsweetened cocoa something i've used in
chili's before to great effect and relax
nobody's gonna be going hey why'd you
put chocolate in my sloppy tom that
seems like a bizarre decision it's
really not enough where you're gonna
taste it but it does add a little hint
of something something that i think
really works here so up to you if you're
a big time wuss don't add it but i would
all right so once all the ingredients
are in the pan i'm gonna add a big
splash of water i'm gonna stir that in
and all we're gonna do here is cook this
over medium heat again we're going to
stay on medium heat and we're just going
to keep cooking it adding water when
needed to keep that kind of pasty
texture all right you see that i kind of
want to keep it that texture so just
keep cooking and cooking every once in a
while when you think it needs it add
another splash of water and as you cook
it of course it's going to reduce and
thicken up a little bit so maybe i added
two three splashes of water during the
cooking process but anyway nothing too
complicated if it's too loose let it
cook a little more if it's too dry add
more water and of course you're going to
taste and adjust the seasoning that goes
without saying i know i just said it
anyway and after about 20 minutes you
should have something that looks like
this one clue it's done the onions will
have pretty much disappeared and the
meat will be very very soft and tender
if you still see chunks of uncooked
onions or the meat seems tough and chewy
just let it cook and at that point we're
gonna turn off the heat i'm gonna add a
handful of green onions we have that
sweet cooked in onion flavor this is
gonna give it a little different aspect
something a little brighter to balance
the sweetness and the richness we're
also gonna add a handful of cheddar
cheese and that cheese is gonna give it
a little bit of creaminess a little bit
of richness that it's missing because
the turkey is so lean and when that's
stirred in you're ready to eat i'm gonna
spoon this on some toasted sesame
hamburger rolls if you love your family
you'll toast the buns first all right
i'm gonna pile that up throw that top
bun on there all right not straight on
top though you want a little bit of a
gangster lean of course you're gonna
pair this with tater tots the official
side dish of sloppy anything and there
you go the sloppy tom no it's not the
greatest looking plate of food in the
world but that's okay it's called a
sloppy tom not a suave steve so i want
you to appreciate its unconventional
beauty just delicious old school
american comfort food i love sloppy joes
but this was a really great much lighter
and yet still very delicious satisfying
version using turkey a little bit sweet
a little bit spicy a little bit tangy
all right just a very familiar taste you
don't have to think a lot about while
you're eating anyway i hope you give
that a try head over to foodwishes.com
for all the ingredients and more
information as usual and as always
enjoy
you
